body.p:
The commonwealth
v. } Indictment Kenton --
Michael More

To the govenor of Kentucky Your Petitioner Michael More states that a Judgt. was rendered agt. him at the present march term of the Kenton circuit court- for $10000 on an indictment (for suffering a nusance, in a house owned by him in Covington.)

He states that it was in proof of substance, that he had owned the house about one year before march 1865 -- the time of the trial of the indictment -- & that he had notice some 7 or 8 months before the trial in March, that some of the occupants -- his tenants, were Lewed women & some of the men thieves -- there was no proof that he knew the character of any of the women or men were of bad character when he rented the house -- He had them removed from the premises in Jay. 1865.
It was also stated that on one or two occasions there was some fighting in front of the house --
It was also in proof that the men who were living in the house were soldiers & the women thier wives --

Now your petitioner states, that he did not know the character of these soldiers or their wives -- when the house was rented -- & that after he was informed of their character -- only about three months, before he was indicted -- he could not remove them -- He was informed that he could have to no process agt. Soldier wives to turn them out -- and that he did cause them to remove as soon as he could do so --
He asks for a remission of the fine --
Michael Moore

I heard the testimony in the above case -- it iswas substantially as stated above -- I do not believe that More could have removed the persons from the house, sooner, than was done after he was informed of their character -- I know More well & do not think he
would, Suffer such persons to live in his houses if he could have prevented it -- I am satisfied that the fine ought to be remitted -- I was his atto-defending --
Jas. Pryor
We heard the testimony -- The statement of it by More is, in substance correct. we ask that the fine may be remitted --
I Was one of the Jury & I think the Fine to Heavy For the offence
Thomas Reed.

I heard some of the evidence, but I know Moore, whilst the parties were said to be in his house he frequently expressed to me his anxiety to get them out of his house. I do not believe Moore would willingly keep such persons in his house.
I agree with the above
N. A. Preston Mayor, C. C.
I know M Moore and from all I can learn he done all he could to eject the tenants from his House And I am confident he would not rent to such characters knowingtly
A L Greer
I know that Mr Moore has been verry much anoyed by these parties and I further believe that under the Law it is not in the power of Mr Moore to dispossess the wife of a soldier

A. H. Herod ^Jailor^
T. L. Reed
To the Govenor of Kentucky

I am a constable and have done a Seved a large number of notices for Michael Moore in thast year for the possession of houses he being the owner of a great many Some of the woman have husbands in the army and it is contended by Some that they cannot be put ourt in I was Stoped by the mitary authereties here on one occasion for Som tim in ecxecuing the writ March 21st 1865
L. M. Rees

I Certify that I am A Justice of the peace for Said County and know that Michael Moore
has used the means to get the possession of Said House and the late Law prohibated him and Several others See acts (63-4 p 48
Benj Egelston J. P. K. C

p.note:
I was one of the Jury in this Case and Believe the Statement of Squir Benj Egelston and L. M. Rease Substantially true,
N. W. Bowen
